title: R42583
content: Since the 1930s, federal job training and employment programs have aimed to connect vulnerable youth to work and school. These young people are typically low-income with barriers to employment, such as dropping out of school or being in foster care. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provides job training and services for unemployed individuals, including youth. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 authorizes job training programs for adults, youth, and dislocated workers, as well as adult education, employment services, and vocational rehabilitation. Youth job training programs under Title I include WIA Youth Activities, Job Corps, and YouthBuild. The federal job training system for youth aims to provide opportunities for vulnerable youth to connect to work and school. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 authorizes job training programs for adults, youth, and dislocated workers. WIA Youth Activities, Job Corps, and YouthBuild are part of the federal job training system for youth, aiming to connect them to educational and employment opportunities. WIA programs continue to be funded through annual appropriation acts, with potential reauthorization in the 112th Congress. This report provides an overview of issues pertinent to WIA youth programs and discusses relevant provisions of H.R. 803. This report discusses issues related to WIA youth programs, including Youth Activities and Job Corps. It also covers provisions of two bills: H.R. 803 and Workforce Investment Act of 2013 (S. 1356). Job training and employment services for youth under WIA include WIA Youth Activities and Job Corps. The Workforce Investment Act (WIA) includes various programs such as WIA Youth Activities, Job Corps, YouthBuild, Reintegration of Ex-Offenders, and Youth Opportunity Grants (YOG) that provide job training and employment services for youth. Youth Opportunity Grants (YOG) is a program funded through FY2003 that created centers in low-income communities for youth to receive employment and other services. WIA's authorization expired in FY2003, but Congress continues to appropriate funds for youth job training programs, except for the YOG program. Job Corps is administered separately by ETA's Office of Job Corps. The Job Corps program, administered by DOL's Employment and Training Administration, connects low-income youth to educational and employment opportunities. YouthBuild is for high school dropouts, while the Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program focuses on youth offenders and those at risk of dropping out. The YouthBuild program is for high school dropouts and focuses on youth offenders and those at risk of dropping out. It provides employment and educational services related to housing and construction work. Job Corps is the only program that offers residential services. The programs provide employment and educational services related to housing and construction work. Job Corps offers residential services for youth. The Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program includes mentoring, educational services, and reentry services for youth returning from secure facilities. Funding for Youth Activities is allocated by DOL to states based on a formula. The Department of Labor allocates funding for Youth Activities to states based on a formula, which is then distributed to local Workforce Investment Boards. DOL partners with nonprofit and for-profit organizations to operate Job Corps centers and cooperates with the USDA Forest Service for Job Corps programs on USDA lands. YouthBuild and the Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program award grants to nonprofit organizations and local communities. Congress is working on reauthorizing the Workforce Investment Act.
